newsitem.title: FRANCE: French police hold three for Corsica car bomb.
newsitem.headline: French police hold three for Corsica car bomb.

text.p: French police detained three people in Corsica on Wednesday in connection with a car bomb that killed a nationalist leader last July, police said.
The arrests were part of a crackdown on separatist guerrillas ordered by Prime Minister Alain Juppe following a new flare-up of separatist violence on the Mediterranean island.
Bombs have exploded on the holiday island every night since the outlawed Corsican National Liberation Front (FLNC) Historic Wing called off a shaky truce three weeks ago.
The latest two rocked a state employment agency and a bar overnight, causing damage but no injuries.
The first explosion late on Tuesday shattered the windows and damaged the employment office in Ile Rousse in the north of the French Mediterranean island. No one claimed responsibility.

Over an hour later, a small bomb damaged the metal shutter of the Le Rallye bar in the island capital Ajaccio in the south. No one claimed responsibility but police found the words "Danger, mine, Arabs Out" scrawled on a wall.

The latest arrests were connected to the car bomb killing of a leader of the movement Cuncolta Naziunalista, the FLNC's legal wing. The attack, in Bastia, was believed to be part of a bloody war between rival separatist groups disagreeing on objectives and tactics.

Paris anti-terrorism magistrates have launched a probe into six suspected members or sympathisers of FLNC following the upsurge in violence. Four were placed in preventive detention and two freed on bail.
Prime Minister Alain Juppe has repeatedly pledged to crack down on Corsican guerrillas pushing for greater autonomy from Paris, but few have been detained.
